paragraphs.content: Ecclesiastes or, the Preacher
paragraphs.contentHtml: Ecclesiastes<small></small> <small>or, the Preacher</small>

paragraphs.content: Chapter 1
paragraphs.contentHtml: Chapter 1

paragraphs.content: The words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.
paragraphs.contentHtml: The words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.

paragraphs.content: Vanity of vanities, saith the Preacher, vanity of vanities; all is vanity.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Vanity of vanities, saith the Preacher, vanity of vanities; all is vanity.

paragraphs.content: What profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun?
paragraphs.contentHtml: What profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun?

paragraphs.content: One generation passeth away, and another generation cometh: but the earth abideth for ever.
paragraphs.contentHtml: One generation passeth away, and another generation cometh: but the earth abideth for ever.

paragraphs.content: The sun also ariseth, and the sun goeth down, and hasteth to his place where he arose.
paragraphs.contentHtml: The sun also ariseth, and the sun goeth down, and hasteth to his place where he arose.

paragraphs.content: The wind goeth toward the south, and turneth about unto the north; it whirleth about continually, and the wind returneth again according to his circuits.
paragraphs.contentHtml: The wind goeth toward the south, and turneth about unto the north; it whirleth about continually, and the wind returneth again according to his circuits.

paragraphs.content: All the rivers run into the sea; yet the sea is not full; unto the place from whence the rivers come, thither they return again.
paragraphs.contentHtml: All the rivers run into the sea; yet the sea is not full; unto the place from whence the rivers come, thither they return again.

paragraphs.content: All things are full of labour; man cannot utter it: the eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
paragraphs.contentHtml: All things are full of labour; man cannot utter it: the eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.

paragraphs.content: The thing that hath been, it is that which shall be; and that which is done is that which shall be done: and there is no new thing under the sun.
paragraphs.contentHtml: The thing that hath been, it is that which shall be; and that which is done is that which shall be done: and there is no new thing under the sun.

paragraphs.content: Is there any thing whereof it may be said, See, this is new? it hath been already of old time, which was before us.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Is there any thing whereof it may be said, See, this is new? it hath been already of old time, which was before us.

paragraphs.content: There is no remembrance of former things; neither shall there be any remembrance of things that are to come with those that shall come after.
paragraphs.contentHtml: There is no remembrance of former things; neither shall there be any remembrance of things that are to come with those that shall come after.

paragraphs.content: ¶ I the Preacher was king over Israel in Jerusalem.
paragraphs.contentHtml: ¶ I the Preacher was king over Israel in Jerusalem.

paragraphs.content: And I gave my heart to seek and search out by wisdom concerning all things that are done under heaven: this sore travail hath God given to the sons of man to be exercised therewith.
paragraphs.contentHtml: And I gave my heart to seek and search out by wisdom concerning all things that are done under heaven: this sore travail hath God given to the sons of man to be exercised therewith.

paragraphs.content: I have seen all the works that are done under the sun; and, behold, all is vanity and vexation of spirit.
paragraphs.contentHtml: I have seen all the works that are done under the sun; and, behold, all is vanity and vexation of spirit.

paragraphs.content: That which is crooked cannot be made straight: and that which is wanting cannot be numbered.
paragraphs.contentHtml: That which is crooked cannot be made straight: and that which is wanting cannot be numbered.

paragraphs.content: I communed with mine own heart, saying, Lo, I am come to great estate, and have gotten more wisdom than all they that have been before me in Jerusalem: yea, my heart had great experience of wisdom and knowledge.
paragraphs.contentHtml: I communed with mine own heart, saying, Lo, I am come to great estate, and have gotten more wisdom than all they that have been before me in Jerusalem: yea, my heart had great experience of wisdom and knowledge.

paragraphs.content: And I gave my heart to know wisdom, and to know madness and folly: I perceived that this also is vexation of spirit.
paragraphs.contentHtml: And I gave my heart to know wisdom, and to know madness and folly: I perceived that this also is vexation of spirit.

paragraphs.content: For in much wisdom is much grief: and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow.
paragraphs.contentHtml: For in much wisdom is much grief: and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow.
